prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: SG1 Band 7
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
- detect any compact mm continuum sources as a signature of a nascent HCHII regions, hence clearly demontrating the presence of a HMYSO in a very early-stage of formation.
- look for signature of an associated disk and/or outflow.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: In order to identify what the methanol maser structures are actually tracing, we wish to observe a selection of methanol thermal lines (to probe the extent and the underlying morpholgy traced by the methanol radiation field as a whole), a reasonable range of methyl cyanide lines, proven to be a good density probe for disk around hot core (S\'anchez-Monge et al. 2014) and at least one good outflow tracer: SiO. While outflows are expected to have high velocities and do not request very high spectral resolution, putative Keplerian disks around hot cores are expected to have rather small rotation velocities (<10 km/s) and request high spectral resolution.

With a typical dimension of the observed elliptical methanol rings of several 100 mas (i.e 0.1 to 0.5 arcsec), a resolution of 0.1", with the largest scale recoverable of 1.4" is needed for the purpose of the project.

Taking a typical 4 kpc for the distance of the selected objects, and assuming a dust temperature of Td=50 K, a continuum sensitivity of 1 mJy will allow us to detect an object of 0.025 solar masses within/over a 100 mas radius which we want to detect with a SNR of 10. The setting selected also provides a peak flux density per synthesized beam, for the CH3CN lines, of 20 mJy/beam to be detected with a SNR also of 10.

The data rate resulting from our correlator setup is slightly higher than the policy value of 12.00 MB/s due to the spectral resolution of 0.4 km/s needed for the disk-tracers methyl cyanide and methanol lines.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Class-II 6.7-GHz methanol masers are known to be found in the circumstellar environment of high-mass young stellar objects (HMYSOs) in their earliest-stages of evolution. High angular resolution observations with VLBI instruments in this maser transition, has revealed the presence of ring-like or linear structures with typically sizes of few 100 to a few 1000 AU. A natural explanation for these structures is that they trace disks around the YSOs. But so far, there is no clear complementary evidence that this hypothesis is indeed correct, and the exciting sources of such structures remain elusive. The resolution, sensitivity and multi-frequency capability of ALMA where very young massive (proto)-star are bright, make it the ideal instrument to search for these sources. The primary goal of this proposal is to identify the sources exciting the Class-II 6.7-GHz methanol masers. The second aim is to identify the underlying physical structures that produce these ring-like or linearly distributed 6.7-GHz methanol masers.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Jodrell Bank Centre for Astrophysics, Manchester, University of
